Entry.1: Received a wire from Lily to effect that Dad is at Eastbourne & she has wired him. No more news of leave yet. Luna Park Hosp. crowd were told today on parade that they are disbanded now & to be split up. That is good – all the more for drafts. Everybody went to Tidworth RAMC sports today – no parades – I stayed in in case dad should come. Writing letters & cleaning up generally.
Entry.4:
Dad arrived on Friday last to my great pleasure, & after we had had a good yarn, & he had made himself friendly with the W.O. Maxwell (temp while Pollard was away) he managed to get me leave till the Monday night

All my hopes since enlisting were thus satisfied, & in just the way I had hoped.

Lily has grown a nice young lady now, & it was a delight to see her again after my long absence. She was tremendously excited but not more than I.

On Sat. I went to see Frances she was the only one at home, except Mrs A but was expecting Violet at any moment, in response to my card Arranged for following night.

Dad & I went to & found Bowles manager. Thence to Lily at Prudential & lunch at Slater’s.

We saw Mr Manhattan at the Prince of Wales’ Theatre & in the evening brought a very pleasant day to a close, Am seeing “The Battle of the Somme” on the Pictures. On Sunday I saw Mr & Mrs Upjohn & Hilda & the youngsters

In the evening Lily Hammond Frances Vi & Ernest, came & we spent a pleasant evening

Had to see Dad back to Caterham unfortunately at about 9, but hope to see him again soon.

On Monday early I saw Mr Hammond Senr. & spent the rest of the day in the city with Lily, Ernest, Frances & Violet.

Caught the 10.43 pm back, Lily & Mrs Elerage, seeing me off. It was a very short time to have at home, & I was very miserable when I got back, but it was a very pleasant memory.

I could not have wished for a pleasanter reunion of all my old associates -- except School, -- they were on holiday.

London is not much changed & everybody was much as before, except the girls who of course are growing up.

It was strange to have the streets dark after about 8 & to see so many searchlights about.

There was a raid somewhere about Woolwich the night I reached London, or the night before --- I am not certain which.
Entry.5:
No letters from Lily since arrived back, nor from Hammonds.

Billy is going to town tomorrow & I hope to go for next week-end.

Went to see “Within the Law” on Thursday last,
but of
 yesterday afternoon went onto Tidworth per motor (traction engine).

Bought 9 rolls of films for the V.P.K. camera which I have bought for 15/-.

I have also bought today, some printing frames & dishes, but I shall not take these away with me. They can keep them for me at home. 3/6 was not dear for them

Church parade in Institute this morning. Received ‘Weekly Times’ from Dad.

Was sent up for medical board yesterday, on account of report re eyes, by Dr 

Passed in A Class!
Entry.6:
Billy went to London with a programme of how to make the most of his four days, including two visits home.

On the following morning W.O. Pollard late of the
Entry.7:
F.A., & now in charge of A.M.C. details, asked on parade for a dispenser & clerk & also for 6 orderlies.

I fulfilled the first requirements & six others were selected including Jimmy Hyde, both of whom were in the dispensary at Marseilles.

Given charge of party by seniority under Capt Rhodes also travelling with us to No 2 Command Depot, Weymouth.

Went by 12-10 pm train via Andover & Southampton West, at both of which places we changed.

Arrived at Weymouth at 4 pm & after 2½ miles march, reached the camp which is at Monte Video out near the sea west of Portland Bill, at tea time. 

First impressions of camp good – given good tea & temporary shakedown in hut.

Wednesday Following morning were allocated work in Hut 83 – a ward – after medical inspection etc. etc.

I, of course, explained for what I was sent down, & Sgt. said I should in due course be sent into dispensary.

Subsequently found out that Cpl dispenser was to be drafted with permanently unfits for Australia on Sunday & I was to take his place

(Positively refuse to conjecture on whether I shall get promotion

out of this, for I know the army now, & with that knowledge I decidedly think I shall 
not
).

Meanwhile, from Wednesday to Saturday I was doing the dirty work of the ward on excellent food – the best for many a weary month.

After already doing 12 hours on Saturday I was told to take charge of Hut 40, the reception hut, for another 12 on night duty.

Took advantage of the lack of work to take gaslight prints of the
Entry.9:
rolls of films I have taken with

the camera

The results were excellent & exceeded my expectations, assuring me of the quality of the lens.

The first roll, which I developed myself was good, but on account of the rainy weather, not nearly a good advertisement for the camera.
Entry.10:
Had the day off, but after bathing spent most of it sleeping.

I have now commenced my second (& I believe last)

night on duty in Hut 40. Last night we only had four new arrivals & tonight about the same will come I was told.

Was told by the Corporal in change of the dispensary, (
not
 the Corp. dispenser) that I start there next week.

It should be a change for the better.

Am now going to write a letter to dear old Rita.

The night is far advanced. A drunken soldier wearing both South African ribbons

has been accommodated temporarily here tonight, for some reason or other – I think he has no room in his own quarters.

Paddy an oldish Irishman in this hut brought him in. Both of them are hardened old wanderers & for some time they conducted a semi drunken conversation about Florida, San Francisco & other places interspersed with platitudes on the war.

After any amount of false alarms common in such cases Paddy succeeded in getting away & leaving the drunk in his bed.

At intervals since then the 

poor chap has been mumbling & chattering in his sleep, broken fragments of nonsense & behind them are the hard years & harder experiences he has had.

Two years hard fighting in this war & as much in South Africa, many a rough brawl in a low down saloon I’ll be bound &, drunk

That will be the end of him I fear.

A patch of grey on either side of his head & a hardened & lined face

 are the outside indicators. A typical derilect, with no 

controlling power to keep him out of the damnable currents into which all world wanders must drift.

And then men scoff at religion. In a community of what use are such men? as he? They do the bullocking work but then they cause brawls & counteract that by the necessity for extra police etc.

They are good soldiers, none better & as such at least are a distinct acquisition to a community.

But does it all end there? Their enemy is distinctly themselves.
Entry.11:
On Tuesday I started work at the dispensary

I have to keep a few stock mixtures supplied, make up special prescriptions for the hospital, & other things such as ointments.

There is not a great deal of dispensing to do, & I am under the Corpl. L/C --- Cap. Binger There are three others who attend to the dressings; among them a Lance Corpl.

My £10 arrived from Australia yesterday, showing that Rita is alright, but I have had no letters yet. She might be sick for all I 

know, it is worrying. I almost wish she would come over here & marry me. It would 
be better I think. Anyhow letters should come soon. 

This week is the anniversary week of my trip from Alexandria to the Peninsula.

Shall I be here or in France, or back in Australia this time next year?

Either of the last two I imagine.

Have heard from Dad & Lily Vi & Ernest & Frances, also from Rushbrooke, who simply sent the card with “absolved” written on it.

A short way of forgiving me for not calling on him.
Entry.12:
Received today a batch of letters including 2 from dear Rita.

One was written in April, the
Entry.14:
In the former Rita refers to having seen Mrs Fothergill that week.

In another letter from Greta Mattlas of a later date I learnt that poor old Fothergill was killed in action in Egypt on
Entry.15:

I also received a long letter that I had written to Rita, back again, because I had

in a fit of mental aberration, addressed it to Grafton London. There were two letters from Greta Mattlas , one from Vi Nichol & one from H. Clarence who is in Bulford Mt’y hospital with Rheumatics.

Billy Molloy is an orderly at that hospital now, so they might meet.

Have got leave for London this week end till Monday night. I hope to get away on Friday night & make three clear days of it.

Getting along alright in the dispensary.

The fellows are very decent to

work with 

of that, more anon.
Entry.16:
Have had another week-end in London since I wrote last in this book.

Saw Rushy at the School on the Monday morning and chatted with several masters, including Nixon, McNair, Hope & Kingdom.

Paid 7/-, the subscription for 2 years Elizabethan membership.

Was not exceedingly pleased with reception which was hardly enthusiastic. Possibly because I have not risen above a Pte, or for other reasons.

Since my return have worked

fairly hard for we have been very busy.

Had three evenings in town with two ladies, one of them the girl who gets my washing every week & the other, her sister.

The former, known to the boys as Rosey, has a young man at the front. He was reported missing unofficially,
abut
 about a couple of months ago, but this week the report came through officially.

She is a good girl & as she was disposed to go out to cheer herself up, I saw no harm in taking her with her sister.

Have also done some photography with fair success.

My latest ideas for pushing forward are two.

One is to apply for a commission in the infantry & the other, to take a course with the University Correspondence College, with a view to passing the London Matric. Have applied for particulars of the latter & am finding out about the former.

The weather is colder, duller, windier & rainier than a month ago. It is seldom we have a 
sunshine
 sunny day, but I like it just the same, for it is England.
Entry.17:
Chief happenings of the week are that I have applied for commission, but failed hopelessly on the eyesight affair.

Major McWhae, who did not seem disposed for me to leave here, told me he thought it hopeless for me to send the application in. Only 3 Australians per month are sent to the School.

He offered to do his best to get me promoted to full corporal after Corp. Binger’s is confirmed. That will probably be some time ahead, but he is a man of his word is McWhae.

Received more letters from Base including 2 from

Poor old Jack died on the
Entry.22:

In October he collapsed at Boulogne through ear trouble & after four operations at the Queen Alexandra Hosp. Malo-les-Bains, he developed pneumonia & bronchitis,

Went to London for three days
Entry.24:
& had a few hours with Dad & Lily.

Everything here is as it was before.

9;XII:16

In the new hut am well installed with a dispensary to myself

Plenty of work & no reply yet concerning establishment & my promotion

Nurses arrived today

The camp is slowly but surely being turned into a hospital.

Hope the nurses will turn out good, & not of the interfering kind.
Entry.25:
Rather a long gap since I last wrote in here, & plenty to write too.

The sisters arrived & turned out to be splendid.

Work increased & the dispensary hut was cleaned out to be renovated in common with some dozen others; the others to form a new hospital here

A partitioned off dispensary was to form part of the improvement

When work had just started Sgt Clay returned to the
Entry.26:
& on leaving promised to see about what chances I would have of getting job of dispenser with them

Soon after he left I decided not to hang on any longer unless I could see substantial reasons for doing so. Told Major Betts that I wished to have my Corp rank confirmed & he sent off a strong recommendation to Col McWhae, who is now A.D.M.S.

Then a letter arrived from Clay saying he could get me the job & so, having heard that the chances of confirmation were poor I decided to get over to France.

No sooner had I decided that I that I heard from the Major that a qualified chemist must be here, & consequently I should

be sent to another depot to work with a Staff Sergeant. My plans turned out to be wise.

Immediately I got six days sick leave & went home on Monday night last week, returning on Saturday.

Lily & I had a good time; I saw dad at Caterham on the Tuesday & he came up on Saturday.

On returning I sent some music & other things including post cards, to Rita.

I shall have to suspend the I.C.S. course just when I have almost finished the second subject: - Arithmetic, but that

cannot be helped.

The £20 I cabled for to pay off the cost at once had not arrived when I was in London, but is at the Bank of N.S.W. as I find from a delayed letter.

To day is Wednesday & I expect to leave for Parkhouse on Friday.
Entry.27:
To day is Saturday & I have not left yet, & probably shall not until next week.

Clarence called here & missed me this week

Bad news from Australia

Just when I am on the of going over a letter from Rita arrives telling me she is willing to come over in the summer.

I wonder if I shall be back by then, or still at it over there, or under the ground

“On ne peut pas jamais dire” !

I have been wondering lately what is really prompting me to go over.

A conscientious desire to be in the thick of it & doing my duty like the poor beggars over there now is undoubtedly a great factor. Mixed up with

that there is a desire for promotion of a substantial kind, & also------ well I had better not write the third reason.

I suppose the other two weigh equally with me & together form the principal stimulus
Entry.28:
Got marching orders yesterday morning to go by myself to Parkhouse by authority of the A.D.M.S.

Caught 12.5 from Weymouth & was seen off by Rosa.

Missed changing at Ludgershall & went a few miles over to a place called – curiously enough –GRAFTON! Delayed two

hours in waiting for train to return by, but beguiled the time in taking tea & listening to a little music at a cottage.

Arrived at Tidworth at 8 pm & then walked three miles with pack & kit bag (through flooded roads at parts) to Parkhouse.

Not worried by the cold & general bad conditions a bit, for I am feeling rather fit.

Saw Major Johnson on arrival & he told me that no hope of going for week or two.

Paraded at 9 this morning & was made to revert to Private as rank only acting.

It seems that my chance of

getting back to the
Entry.29:
& incidentally the dispensary job, is not great.

Never mind, keep a good heart & all will be well. I’ve left for the front again & am quite prepared for any misfortune that may come my way. My good luck in living so long counteracts any hard luck I have had in not getting promotion

A la victoire.
Entry.30:
Unexpectedly put on draft yesterday.

Handed in all spare kit today.

On guard from 5 p.m. yesterday till 5 p.m. today.

Probably leave here tomorrow.
